slides.title: Key Figures & Quotes

john_f_kennedy.name: John F. Kennedy
background: Set the Moon landing goal (1961 Rice speech).
Catalyzed Apollo funding, schedule, and national focus.
john_f_kennedy.quote: We choose to go to the Moon in this decade and do the other things, not because they are easy, but because they are hard.

neil_armstrong.name: Neil Armstrong
background: Commander, Apollo 11; first human on the Moon.
Test pilot; Gemini and Apollo astronaut.
neil_armstrong.quote: That’s one small step for [a] man, one giant leap for mankind.

bill_anders.name: Bill Anders
background: Apollo 8 astronaut; captured the iconic Earthrise photo.
Helped shift public perspective to a fragile Earth.
bill_anders.quote: We came all this way to explore the Moon, and the most important thing is that we discovered the Earth.

gene_cernan.name: Gene Cernan
background: Apollo 17 commander; last human to walk on the Moon (1972).
gene_cernan.quote: We leave as we came, and, God willing, as we shall return, with peace and hope for all mankind.

slides.title: Mission Timeline: Apollo to Artemis

milestones.event: JFK sets Moon goal (within the decade)
Apollo 8: first crewed lunar orbit; Earthrise
Apollo 13: safe return after in-flight anomaly
Apollo 17: last crewed Moon landing of Apollo era
SLS authorized; Orion deep-space capsule baseline
Artemis I: uncrewed SLS/Orion lunar mission
Artemis IV: Gateway assembly; SLS Block 1B (NET)

slides.title: Budget Trends (Inflation-Adjusted)

insights: Apollo peak: NASA ≈4.3% of U.S. federal outlays (1966); constant-$ peak far above current levels.
Artemis era: NASA ≈0.4–0.5% of federal outlays; Exploration accounts rising but below Apollo scale.
Modern costs reflect safety, sustainability, and broader science/LEO programs.
content.notes: Values are indicative and rounded; constant-dollar conversions depend on index choice.

slides.title: Technology Advances: Materials, Computing, Guidance

materials: From aluminum alloys to Al‑Li, composites, and additive-manufactured engine parts.
Thermal protection: ablative heat shields → refined TPS materials and arc‑jet validated repairs.
computing: Apollo Guidance Computer: tens of kilobytes of memory; deterministic real‑time design.
Modern rad‑hard processors: orders‑of‑magnitude more compute; fault tolerance; model‑based FSW.
guidance_navigation_control: Inertial platforms → strapdown IMUs + star trackers + GNSS assist near Earth.
Terrain Relative Navigation (TRN), hazard detection LIDAR, precision powered descent for landers.
systems: Digital twins and HIL testbeds for avionics and propulsion.
Closed‑loop ECLSS improvements; deep‑space comms including optical/laser links.

diagram_spec.callouts: Short 5–7 word advances per spoke; small icons (fiber layup, chip, gyroscope, laser).

slides.title: Risks and Mitigations

pairs.risk: Heat shield/charring behavior in high‑energy reentry
pairs.mitigation: Design refinements; arc‑jet/flight‑like test coupons; instrumented reentry data closeout before crewed flight.
Storm shelters; passive materials; mission timing; dosimetry and operational constraints.

pairs.risk: Lunar landing precision and hazard avoidance
pairs.mitigation: TRN, autonomous hazard detection, rehearsals with uncrewed demos and sims.

pairs.risk: On‑orbit cryogenic propellant transfer for HLS
pairs.mitigation: Incremental demos; boil‑off control; multi‑tanker architecture with ground test correlation.
Interface control, phased verification, margin reserves, independent readiness reviews.
Modular milestones, international cost‑sharing, multi‑year procurement strategies.

slides.title: Cultural Impact

highlights: Earthrise (Apollo 8) and Blue Marble (Apollo 17) reshaped global environmental awareness.
STEM inspiration: generations of scientists, engineers, and explorers.
Shared global moments: live broadcasts, classroom lessons, public art and film.
Artemis expands representation: commitment to land the first woman and first person of color on the Moon.
Commercial era storytelling: new icons, new access, broader participation.

slides.title: What’s Next

near_term_0_3y: Artemis II crewed lunar flyby (NET 2025); validate life support and reentry.
Artemis III lunar landing (NET 2026) using HLS; science at the south polar region.
CLPS missions delivering instruments and tech demos.
mid_term_3_7y: Gateway assembly (power/prop, habitation, logistics) enabling longer stays.
SLS Block 1B and Orion upgrades; more mass to deep space.
Surface systems: mobility, power, and initial ISRU experiments.
longer_term_7y_plus: Sustained lunar presence: repeat landings, expanded science and technology cycles.
Pathfinding for Mars: ECLSS closure, radiation countermeasures, propulsion ops.
International and commercial growth of a cislunar economy.
content.notes: Schedules and content subject to change with testing outcomes, policy, and partner readiness.
